<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_dma_unmap:
```c
void metal_dma_unmap(struct metal_device *dev,
		  uint32_t dir,
		  struct metal_sg *sg,
		  int nents)
{
	/* memory barrier */
	if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_R)
		/* If it is device read, apply memory write fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_release);
	else
		/*If it is device write or r/w, apply memory r/w fence */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_acq_rel);

	if (!dev || !dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap || !sg)
		return;
	dev->bus->ops.dev_dma_unmap(dev->bus,
			dev, dir, sg, nents);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_dma_unmap:
#define METAL_DMA_DEV_R 1
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if (dir == METAL_DMA_DEV_R)
		/* If it is device read, apply memory write fence. */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_release);
	else
		/*If it is device write or r/w, apply memory r/w fence */
		atomic_thread_fence(memory_order_acq_rel);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The if/else branches are both potentially reachable: dir is a uint32_t parameter and may have values equal to METAL_DMA_DEV_R (1) or other values, so both the 'if' and the 'else' path can be executed at runtime. There is no compile-time constant that makes one branch impossible, therefore there is no unreachable code in the fragment.
